Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Developing Approaches to the Study of Information - Washington, D.C. April 2018

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop brings together different approaches to studying political information and the way it is used by partisans on all sides of the political divide. This will be done by bringing together experts from various fields such as Communications, Political Science, Social Psychology, etc. These experts have addressed a number of different aspects of this topic from a variety of methodological and theoretical points of view. Specifically, they will address what factors drive politically motivated perceptions? How effective are correctives to misinformation? The workshop would address these questions by bringing together experts from different disciplines/sub-disciplines who have addressed these questions in different ways.

The objectives of the workshop are to structure intellectual change, clarify the state of the field, prioritize remaining questions, and chart a collaborative and efficient research agenda going forward. The focus will be on distinguishing causal paths that impact the interpretations of political information, document its consequences, and evaluative ways to deal more efficiently with misinformation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conference

During the Spring of 2018, David Barker and Elizabeth Suhay hosted “The Politics of Truth” conference at American University’s Constitution Hall. The primary goal of this conference was to structure intellectual exchange among the nation’s leading authorities on the problem of misinformation in the political sphere, to synthesize knowledge on that topic and identify remaining questions, and, finally, to chart a collaborative research agenda, including a possible edited volume.

We invited top scholars from around the country to the conference, and over twenty attended. Attendees external to AU who participated in the program included: Kevin Arceneaux (Temple), Adam Berinsky (MIT), Cheryl Boudreau (UC Davis), Kim Fridkin (ASU), Cary Funk (Pew), Don Haider-Markel (Kansas), Danny Hayes (George Washington), Greg Huber (Yale), Jennifer Jerit (Stony Brook), Jennifer Kavanagh (RAND), Scott Keeter (Pew), Nathan Lee (Stanford), Arthur Lupia (U of Michigan), Morgan Marietta (UMass, Lowell), Joanne Miller (Minnesota), Diana Mutz (U of Pennsylvania), Robert Shapiro (Columbia), John Sides (George Washington), Joe Uscinski (U of Miami), and Amanda Wintersieck (U of Tennessee, Chatanooga). Other scholars from AU and the surrounding area also attended as audience members.

The conference included a full day of original research presentations on the topic of misinformation in the political sphere, organized around four themes: (1) refining and clarifying concepts; (2) distinguishing causal mechanisms; (3) documenting the full range of consequences; and (4) evaluating correctives. David Barker, Elizabeth Suhay, Arthur Lupia, and Diane Mutz served as moderators.

The conference also included two events featuring eminent practitioners. At lunchtime, we hosted a panel on misinformation from an ethical perspective that included Mike McCurry (Wesley Theological Seminary; former White House Press Secretary) and Michael Gerson (The Washington Post; former White House Chief Speechwriter and Senior Policy Advisor), with Betsy Fischer Martin (American University; former producer of Meet the Press) moderating. At the end of the day, we hosted a roundtable on “The Politics of Truth” with four journalists: E.J. Dionne (Washington Post/Georgetown), Robert Costa (Washington Post/PBS Washington Week), Molly Ball (Time/CNN), and Shawna Thomas (Vice News). The roundtable was moderated by Ron Elving (American University/National Public Radio).

Edited Volume

As expected, we have proceeded to craft a proposal to Oxford University Press for a lengthy edited volume entitled The Politics of Truth in Polarized America: Concepts, Causes, and Correctives. We vetted abstracts from conference participants and incorporated them into a proposal to Oxford in Fall 2018. The proposal was met with enthusiasm by its peer reviewers, and we expect to receive a contract from Oxford and have the manuscript in production sometime in 2020.
